comments.body: This is sufficient - remaining processes will end at some point.
Can you add this note into the shell script comments so that it doesn't get lost in github comments.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +52,56 @@    #    be killed)
    # This is sufficient - remaining processes will end after a while.

    local pid
    pid=$(cat "${PIDFILE}" 2> /dev/null)

comments.body:
Is there a reason these lines aren't spelled:

```
if ! pid=$(cat "${PIDFILE}" 2> /dev/null); then
  return 1
fi
```

?

It's more idiomatic to test for return inline unless you need to pocket the return value.
nested bash expressions are horrible - this is the only reason I put it this way.

@@ -1,1 +57,61 @@    if [[ $? != 0 ]]; then
        return 1
    fi
    local pgrp
    # find the process group for the service and kill entire group

comments.body: Do we need some way to sequence the creation of these objects?

I was worried about that, but the parallel spray works fine (at the
moment). In the future I could imagine a rudimentary approach using tsort.

wrote:

> :
> 
> > +
> > +# PATH should only include /usr/\* if it runs after the mountnfs.sh script
> > +PATH=/sbin:/usr/sbin:/bin:/usr/bin
> > +DESC="Kubernetes Addon Object Manager"
> > +NAME=kube-addons
> > +DAEMON_LOG_FILE=/var/log/$NAME.log
> > +PIDFILE=/var/run/$NAME.pid
> > +SCRIPTNAME=/etc/init.d/$NAME
> > +KUBECTL=/usr/local/bin/kubectl
> > +
> > +# Define LSB log_\* functions.
> > +# Depend on lsb-base (>= 3.2-14) to ensure that this file is present
> > +# and status_of_proc is working.
> > +. /lib/lsb/init-functions
> > +
> > +function addon_manager_async() {
> 
> Do we need some way to sequence the creation of these objects?
> 
> 窶能n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/pull/3601/files#r23243941
> .

This might not work for monitoring since it requires an 'InfluxDB' service to be setup before starting heapster controller. This requirement should go away once heapster starts using DNS. I will work on a PR to make heapster use DNS.

The objects seem to have no trouble being created, no matter what order I fed them in. The services in the pods themselves can't really be relied on to start in a particular order (nor was kube-up.sh actually testing that any particular service was up before creating the next set of pods). (Please note that the `initd` script is actually doing a parallel start on everything, so DNS will probably come up pretty rapidly anyways, but there are no guarantees.)

I did some basic spot checking on the monitoring dashboard after these changes and it looked fine, but there's not a whole lot of testing here. So I think we're fine here unless you're sure there's a problem.
To make this predictable, we will need DNS to be up before starting monitoring and logging services.
Define 'up'? Everything in (now) `/etc/kubernetes/addons/dns` created? The service is healthy? The service has been healthy for N minutes and isn't flapping?

Also, this isn't actually true today. Existing `kube-up.sh` semantics call `setup-monitoring`, which create the `cluster/addons/cluster-monitoring` objects, then create DNS.

I suspect what happens is that monitoring comes up and gropes around in the dark for DNS, and then eventually gets it and starts working. Which is fine. That's actually a reasonable approach for service finalization.
I take back my comment - the apps can be made resilient to DNS issues. By 'up' I meant a healthy service. cc @satnam6502 to make sure that DNS is not a hard requirement for logging.

The current monitoring setup does not rely on DNS. It relies on environment
variables for the purposes of service discovery.

comments.body:
What happens if a user wants to push a new config for these things?  I'm guessing that we don't support that for now. We might want to document that as part of kube-push.sh.

Also, this'll error if the master machine reboots.  We also need to make sure that on a reboot this guy comes up after the apiserver -- or perhaps waits/retries until the apiserver is ready.

> # Required-Start: $local_fs $network $syslog kube-apiserver

Yes, it'll error if restarted for now. It's a bit of a wart.

What I really want is "create or update".

I might've misunderstood your comment a bit, though. The only error you see is actually in the `/var/log/kube-addons.log`, and it's relatively obvious that it completed with mild errors. Is this worth fixing right now?

Is there hope down the line for an atomic create-or-update op? Because the robust approach without it is probably to do something like "if create fails, try update .. if that fails, we had a real error", but even that is a guess.
